channel.title: JAD - The free Java decompiler :)
channel.description:
Figured that I would post this, just because.
[url=http://www.kpdus.com/jad/winnt/jadnt158.zip]Jad 1.5.8g for Windows 9x/NT/2000 on Intel platform[/url]
[url=http://www.kpdus.com/jad/macosx86/jadmx158.zip]Jad 1.5.8g for Mac OS X 10.4.6 on Intel platform[/url]
[url=http://www.kpdus.com/jad/hpux/jadhp158.zip]Jad 1.5.8e for HP-UX 11.x[/url]
[url=http://www.kpdus.com/jad/linux/jadlx158.zip]Jad 1.5.8e for Linux on Intel platform[/url]

item.title: JAD - The free Java decompiler :)
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

i dno what crazy version of windows you guys are running, but the nearest thing to any of that is the subkey of the type named ‘persistentHandler’ that has the GUID of the program that runs it :o

Read full topic

item.title: JAD - The free Java decompiler :)
item.dc:creator: @popcorn89 popcorn89
item.description:
@popcorn89 wrote:

Check out HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT.java and look at the default value. It’s probably going to be ft00000 something. Whatever it is replace ft000001 in the registry file BobDole posted with that value.

Read full topic

item.title: JAD - The free Java decompiler :)
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

frank_:

it didnt, but uuh, wouldnt ‘ft000001’ be ‘.class’? :\

Not a clue tbh - I couldn’t understand why it wasn’t. In any case, I tested that on a couple comps, and it appeared to work fine. I’ll look into it though

Read full topic

item.title: JAD - The free Java decompiler :)
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

ft00000whatever000 is a number representing the user. It’s usually something like the first one will be 345ayprel, then the next will be 345ayprel_classes, and then for a user made later it will be 345ayprel_5478fdplef and 345ayprel5477fdplef_classes, and etc.

Read full topic

ew, windows

Read full topic

item.title: JAD - The free Java decompiler :)
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:11, topic:55992”][quote author=moparisthebest link=topic=79485.msg876746#msg876746 date=1170929294]

Meh, I use JAD. I don’t think I’ve heard of JODE lol.

Someone explain why it’s better?

  1. written in Java
  2. Open Source GNU/GPL
  3. hosted on sourceforge

Need I say more? (jode.sourceforge.net is the URL)
[/quote]too bad the output of jode looks like a pile of crap eh?

im with bobdole, it is easier to integrate into the shell, i am yet to do it yet though because i am lazy :([/quote]

Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00

[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\ft000001]
"EditFlags"=dword:00000000
"BrowserFlags"=dword:00000008
@=""

[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\ft000001\shell]
@="Decompile"

[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\ft000001\shell\Decompile]

[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\ft000001\shell\Decompile\command]
@="\"C:\\WINDOWS\\jad.exe\" -sjava -nonlb \"%1\""

[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Classes\ft000001]
"EditFlags"=dword:00000000
"BrowserFlags"=dword:00000008
@=""

[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Classes\ft000001\shell]
@="Decompile"

[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Classes\ft000001\shell\Decompile]

[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Classes\ft000001\shell\Decompile\command]
@="\"C:\\WINDOWS\\jad.exe\" -sjava -nonlb \"%1\""

See if that works for ya

Read full topic

item.title: JAD - The free Java decompiler :)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

It is simply better from an open source standpoint, I use JAD when I can, and JODE when JAD breaks. (From experience JODE can successfully decompile when JAD can’t, especially with complicated control structures)

Read full topic

Someone explain why it’s better?
[/quote]

  1. written in Java

  3. hosted on sourceforge

Need I say more? (jode.sourceforge.net is the URL)[/quote]too bad the output of jode looks like a pile of crap eh?

item.title: JAD - The free Java decompiler :)
item.dc:creator: @popcorn89 popcorn89
item.description:
@popcorn89 wrote:

I find it easier to read raw bytecode than to read JODE’s output, but that’s just me.

Read full topic

item.title: JAD - The free Java decompiler :)
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Yep, jad is great. JODE is a better decompiler imo, but I prefer jad to jode as its easier to integrate into the windows shell (ie, double click on a class file to decompile). Most of the time, all you want is a rough version of the source so it doesn’t matter if jad is off a bit.

Read full topic
